Journal Story: So I'm leaving for Atlanta later this week.Â  Looking to slack the approach trail maybe on Friday if timing works out - much to do and seemingly no time to do it.Â  This trip came about on a bit of a whim about six weeks ago, so I am both physically and mentally somewhat underprepared for this, so will be taking the first few weeks slow and steady.Â  I'm not wholly unfamiliar with the Trail - I hiked the Whites as a youth, and have lived in Massachusetts for the last few years, so I have some confidence, but would like to be a month into the hike sooner rather than later.Â  Looking forward to meeting as many of you as possible, and can't wait to get started.

So, this is entry two - Iâ€™m guessing I should discuss how much Iâ€™ve overpacked and what will I do - but Iâ€™ve lived my life so far by the mantra that things will work out - I might end up needing all the cold weather gear Iâ€™ve packed, or I might dump it at the earliest opportunity (until the Whites). So it is the day before I leave and start this bit of fun.Â  I'm admittedly nervous - pretty much the same butterflies and knots I had before starting the various military schools I attended.Â  I'm hoping to see or at least hear some of the Ranger candidates during their Mountain Phase along the TVD.Â  Worried about things like pack weight, doing a respectful yet comfortable number of miles the first few weeks, hoping i have enough of the right gear - have plenty of gear, just not sure it is all the right gear, and just looking forward to getting the first few weeks in the rear view mirror. So travel day is finally here - I'm ready to go, but so ill-prepared for the trail.Â  Like I've said before though, things generally will always work out - it may not be in quite the way you expect, but they will work out.Â  I've got a few knots in my stomach, and I'm dreading opening the box I pre-sent with all of my gear, weighing in at just around 50 pounds. Extra food and winter clothing make up the added weight, but I still feel like I've overpacked, especially in the first aid department, which is something I will not feel too comfortable compromising on.Â  Let's see how that plays out once I've humped a few miles.Â  Thanks to my wife and girls for helping me out on this.Â  And so it begins...

so I will not be posting every day, but I will try to keep this updated. Â I think I only walked around seven miles of the actual trail today. Today was tough. Â  Not so much in the hiking itself, although for reasons I will refer to later, I only made it about three miles today. Â Things I learned:1. Â Stop and take your pack off now and then, and soak you feet in a river. Â Back in the Army days, that pack went on and stayed on your back until mission accomplished. Â There is no mission here.2. Â Use your walking sticks. Â Too many times I found myself mimicking holding an M4 or an M16 at the ready. Â Not helpful anymore.3. Itâ€™s okay for things to dangle off your pack. Â Now, just strap that stuff on as best you can and move out.4.now the reason for the delay - it seems not all Walgreens/CVS stores in North Georgia carry every kind of medication, so I canâ€™t just pop in and ask for a refill. Â Iâ€™ve researched Walgreens up the trail and now know to make the request about a week in advance - yes, the trail does go through or near many towns.
